    If it is not possible to serve anyone in person at the rental property, the landlord may post the notice on the rental property's door or by placing it in some other obvious place. The notice may also be sent by registered or certified mail. There must be clear evidence of notice having been served to a tenant. Some courts in Kansas require a photo of a notice attached to a door if the tenant avoids or refuses service.

    Any notice that is mailed receives an additional 2 days for the tenant to comply. The notice period only includes weekdays and does not include holidays or weekends.

    For nonpayment of rent, the Kansas eviction process requires that a 3-day notice be used. The notice must clearly state the amount of rent owed to the landlord. The notice should inform the problem tenant that the lease will terminate unless the tenant pays the required rent within 3 days. The notice should also inform the tenant that legal action will be pursued if the tenant remains on the premises after not paying the rent within the allotted time period.

    For material noncompliance with the rental agreement (other than nonpayment of rent), the landlord must serve the tenant with a 14/30 day notice. The tenant is allowed 14 days to comply with the particular lease term that is being violated. The notice must state that the lease will terminate 14 days after service of the notice unless the situation is corrected by the tenant.

    The notice must also include that if there is noncompliance with the notice, then the tenant must vacate within the next 30-days or legal action will be taken against the tenant.

    When a month-to-month lease is in place, a landlord can terminate the lease without providing a reason and by giving the tenant a 30 day notice, giving the problem tenant 30 days after the 30-day notice is served to vacate the rental property.

    **Court Actions Required in an Kansas Eviction**

    Should the tenant fail to pay the rent or cure the lease violation and vacate after 30-days, the landlord must file and serve a summons and petition for forcible detainer. The landlord may include in the petition a request for monetary damages including the payment of rent owed.

    **Kansas Eviction Docket Call Actions**

    The court clerk will set a hearing date for a “docket call.” The "docket call" hearing is not less than 3 or more than 14 days after the filing.

    The docket call acts as a preliminary hearing to an eviction hearing in which the court attempts to assist the the parties to resolve their outstanding issue. If the court is not able to facilitate a resolution between the landlord and the tenant, the court schedules a trial within the next 8 days.

    The tenant must appear in person to the hearing and contest the petition or be determined to be in default. If the tenant is found in default, the landlord will be able to move forward with the eviction unopposed.

    **Service of Summons in Kansas**

    The tenant is served with the summons and petition by the local sheriff. This summons and petition advises the tenant of the time, location, and any other logistical details of the court hearing.

    **Court Date for Tenant Eviction in Kansas**

    An eviction hearing is conducted before a judge approximately 8 days after the docket hearing has commenced. The landlord and tenant may present their respective cases but the landlord must prove to the court that the tenant either failed to pay rent to the landlord when rent is due or failed to cure the violation of the lease terms by the time allowed.

    If the landlord wins in court, the court will issue a judgment of possession for the landlord. The tenant will be asked to vacate the rental unit within a set period of time.

    **Judgment and Writ of Restitution in Kansas**

    If the tenant remains at the rental unit after the time period given to vacate, the landlord must obtain a Writ of Restitution from the court. Once the Write of Restitution is given to the sheriff, the sheriff will execute the Writ within 10 days.

    The Write of Restitution empowers the sheriff to remove the tenant and the tenant’s property from the landlord's rental property. A few counties in Kansas require the landlord to supply their own workers to remove the tenant’s possession while being supervised by the local sheriff.

Title: Arkansas Eviction Laws for Landlords
Content:
**Arkansas Eviction Laws for Landlords**

The Arkansas eviction process is very landlord friendly and aggressive against tenants. There is only a very short time for a tenant to remedy any cause for an eviction. An Arkansas landlord may utilize two different eviction procedures when seeking to evict a tenant if the cause of eviction is for nonpayment of rent: Unlawful Detainer, which is a civil eviction, or Failure to Vacate, which is a criminal eviction.

The Arkansas eviction process is the only one in the United States that makes it a misdemeanor for a tenant to not pay rent if the landlord chooses to evict the tenant via the “failure to vacate” process. Please note that if the eviction is for a violation of lease terms than Failure to Vacate is not an option for a landlord.

**Legally Valid Reasons to Evict a Tenant in Arkansas**

The legally valid reasons a landlord may evict a tenant in Arkansas include:
  • If a tenant fails to pay rent in accordance with the written lease agreement.
  • If a tenant violates any term or rule stated within the Lease or Rental Agreement.
  • If a tenant commits specific criminal acts at the rental property. The criminal acts include illegal gambling, prostitution, and the sale of alcohol without a license.

    **There is No Self-Eviction in Arkansas**

    A landlord may NOT evict a tenant in the State of Arkansas without an order authorizing an eviction which requires a court hearing by a local judge. Self-eviction includes any action taken by the landlord outside of the normal legal process in Arkansas that is designed to force the tenant to vacate the premises.

    **Arkansas Eviction Notice Requirements**

    For nonpayment eviction cases where the landlord chooses the unlawful detainer method of eviction, the Arkansas eviction notice process requires a 3-day Notice to Quit to be served on the tenant by either the landlord or the landlord’s agent. The tenant is only given 3 days to pay the entire rent amount that is outstanding. The date the notice is served counts as the first day.

    If the landlord chooses to use the failure to vacate method, which may only be used for cases of nonpayment of rent, the landlord must serve written notice giving the tenant 10 days to comply.

    If a landlord wishes to terminate the lease agreement because of material violations of the rental agreement, the landlord must provide the tenant a 14 day notice to comply or to correct the problem. The notice needs to clearly specify the particular lease provision that has been violated and inform the tenant that compliance must be done by a listed date.

    If the tenant is accused of breaking the law, the landlord can give the tenant a quit notice with no qualifications.

    If there is no written rental agreement, a landlord may terminate the lease at any time and for any reason but must give the tenant one period (normally a month as most are month to month) of advanced notice, called the Arkansas Lease Termination Notice.

    Any Arkansas eviction notice requirements specified in the written lease agreement must be followed by the landlord and the tenant.

    **Court Actions Required in an Arkansas Eviction**

    If the problem tenant has not remedied the situation or removed themselves from the rental unit in the allotted amount of time, then the landlord must file one of two actions against the tenant.

    If the eviction is for nonpayment of rent, the landlord may file the civil unlawful detainer case or file the criminal failure to vacate case. A landlord may not file both of these actions against a tenant. If the eviction is for a violation of the lease terms, the landlord may only file an unlawful detainer action.

    **The Two Eviction Options in Arkansas**

    **Unlawful Detainer**

    A tenant has five (5) days after being served to file an objection with the court. If the tenant files no objection, the landlord may obtain a Writ of Possession to have the tenant evicted by the sheriff. If the tenant files an objection, the trial continues in two parts.

    **Summary Proceeding:** If the tenant files an objection within the allotted five (5) days, the court will schedule a summary proceeding where the court determines only which party shall have sole possession of the rental property. The landlord only needs to present a prima facie case that the landlord is entitled to possession due to failure to pay rent or present evidence that substantial damage has occurred at the rental property.

    The tenant may present a defense that is in accordance with Arkansas law.

    If the court finds that the landlord is likely to be successful in a full Trial on the Merits, the court will issue a Writ of Possession to the landlord. The landlord must post sufficient security, such as a bond, to proceed with the Writ of Possession.

    If the tenant has presented a defense that the court agrees with and wants to remain in possession of the rental unit, the tenant must post sufficient security within 5 days after the Writ of Possession is issued. The security may be set at whatever amount the court feels is necessary.

    **Failure to Vacate**

    If the landlord has pursued the Failure to Vacate, after the 10 days has lapsed and the rent has not been paid and the tenant has not vacated the property, the landlord may report the tenant to the local prosecutor.

    The local prosecutor may charge the tenant with a class B misdemeanor. The criminal action may be classified as more of a minor violation than a criminal offense. Tenants are not subject to imprisonment through the Failure to Vacate action.

    If charges are brought against the tenant, the court can impose a fine of $1.00 to $25.00 per day for every day the tenant remains in the rental unit after the 10 days. Some counties in Arkansas rarely use this method of eviction. A judge may dismiss the charges if a tenant agrees to vacate the property immediately.

    **Service of Summons and Tenant Counterclaims**

    If the landlord uses the unlawful detainer, or civil method of eviction, the tenant will be served with a Summons and Complaint in Unlawful Detainer once the 3 day or 14 day notice period has expired. Once served, the tenant only has 5 days to file an objection.

    For the failure to vacate option, the sheriff or court representative delivers the summons to the tenant.

    **Court Date for Tenant Eviction in Arkansas**

    **Unlawful Detainer Trial on the Merits**

    If the trial makes it past the Summary Proceedings, a full determination regarding rightful possession and any issues of damages is heard by the court. In most cases, this hearing determines the amount of damages owed to the landlord.

    If a tenant is able to successfully assert a defense such as self-eviction or the landlord’s failure to make obligated repairs the damages may be assessed against the landlord.

    **Failure to Vacate**

    The court under this method cannot order the tenant to vacate the property though any tenant subject to substantial fines will likely vacate at his or her earliest opportunity.

    A low-income tenant is not entitled to a public defender in these cases since there is no potential for a sentence of imprisonment.

    If a tenant does not show for court, Arkansas courts almost always rule in favor of the landlord.

    **Judgment and Writ of Possession in Arkansas**

    A Writ of Possession is only issued for Unlawful Detainer cases, not for failure to vacation cases where the tenant will be fined continuously until they vacate the rental property. In most cases, tenants will not put a bond or post security and will be subject to forcible eviction once the sheriff receives the Writ of Possession and serves it on the tenant.

Title: Tennessee Eviction Laws for Landlords
Content:
# Tennessee Eviction Laws for Landlords
If you are a landlord that owns rental property in the state of Tennessee you'll want to ensure that you understand the real estate law, eviction laws, and the eviction process in the state. Failure to abide by state laws on eviction can result in a lot of legal problems for a landlord and they may have to deal with the problem tenant a lot longer as a result..

A portion of the state’s counties are covered by the Uniform Residential Landlord and Tenant Act (URLTA), which has different notice requirements and processes relating to the landlord-tenant relationship. The 10 counties in Tennessee where landlords must abide by the URLTA are Anderson, Blount, Bradley, Davidson, Hamilton, Madison, Montgomery, Shelby, Sumner and Knox.

**Legally Valid Reasons to Evict a Tenant in Tennessee**

The legally valid reasons a landlord may evict a tenant in Tennessee include:

  • If the tenant fails to pay rent and/or pay rent on time.
  • If the tenant has violated the lease or rental agreement.
  • If the lease term has ended and the tenant does not move out of the rental unit.
  • If the tenant is responsible for noise or safety problems.
  • If the tenant is responsible for illegal activity on the rental unit property.
  • If the tenant has abandoned the property and therefore the lease.

    **There is No Self-Eviction in Tennessee**

    A landlord may NOT evict a tenant in the State of Tennessee without an order authorizing an eviction. This requires a court hearing by a local judge. Self-eviction includes any action taken by the landlord outside of the normal legal process in Tennessee that is designed to force the tenant to vacate the premises.

    **Tennessee Eviction Notice Requirements**

    URLTA Covered Counties in Tennessee In the ten (10) counties that are under the URLTA, a landlord must give a 30-day eviction notice to a tenant who is either behind on rent or who has violated a term of the lease agreement.

    The URLTRA covered Tennessee eviction notice must advise the tenant of the exact amount of rent amount owed or the specific lease provision the tenant is in violation of. The notice must also state that the tenant may correct the violation within a 14-day period or the lease will be cancelled in 30-days and legal action will begin.

    If it is written in the lease agreement, the notice of rent owed may be implied. An example of this is the lease agreement may state that not paying the rent after a specific date constitutes the 30-day notice to vacate, giving the tenant 30 days to move out of the rental unit. If there is no written lease between the tenant and landlord, the landlord must give 30-days notice to the tenant. The landlord does not need to be given a reason for the eviction. This does not allow the landlord to discriminate against the tenant.

    If a tenant remedies the violation only to repeat the identical violation again within 6-months of the initial violation, the landlord must give a 14-day notice to cancel the lease to the tenant. The landlord does not have to give the tenant any ability to remedy the violation in this instance, only the 14 days notice allowance to vacate.

    Non-URLTA Covered Counties in Tennessee For Tennessee counties not covered by the URLTA, landlords must provide a Tennessee eviction notice of 14-days for failure to pay rent, for tenant-caused property damage, or if health and safety violations have occurred. Violations such as having unapproved tenants or pets require a 30-day written notice to correct the issue or vacate the rental property.

    If a tenant has damaged the rental property in a substantial way, assaulted the landlord or another tenant, has threatened violence, or another person living in the rental property has engaged in behavior that poses a risk to the health and safety of others, the notice period to vacate is 3-days and Landlord must serve a 3 day notice.

    A lease may contain terms stating that a notice to correct or quit is implied along with what actions would warrant an eviction. A court must consider the terms reasonable and the terms must not waive any legal or constitutional rights of a tenant.

    Any Tennessee eviction notice may be served by the landlord personally on the tenant, on a co-tenant, by posting it to the door of the rental property or by certified mail.

    If a Tennessee Landlord needs to terminate a month to month tenancy agreement the Landlord should serve a Leased Termination Letter.

    **Court Actions Required in an Tennessee Eviction**

    If a tenant refuses to correct a lease violation and the tenant does not vacate the property in the allotted time, the landlord must obtain a Detainer Warrant from the General Sessions Court or Circuit Court in the Tennessee county that the rental property is located.

    **Tennessee Eviction Detainer Warrant Actions**

    The Detainer Warrant advises the tenant of a court date and time. The court date may not be less than 6 days after the tenant was served, however the parties may request that the trial date be pushed out past this 6 day requirement.

    **Service of Summons and Tenant Counterclaims**

    Landlords requesting monetary damages along with possession of a rental unit being returned to them must serve the Detainer Warrant to the tenant personally.

    The warrant is typically served by the local sheriff or a process server. It may be served personally on the tenant or by posting it on the door of the rental property.

    **Court Date for Tenant Eviction in Tennessee**

    An eviction hearing is a trial before a judge. The tenant’s failure to appear on that day will result in a default judgment for the landlord. The landlord has the burden of proving that the tenant did not pay the rent when due or that he or she violated a specific rule or term within the lease agreement.

    Proper notice must also be proved. Evidence may be presented by providing copies of the lease, notice provided and proof of service, rent receipts, repair estimates, police reports, or witness testimony.

    **Judgment and Writ of Possession in Tennessee**

    If the landlord is granted possession by the court through winning a trial or due to the tenant not showing, the tenant will be given 10-days to vacate the rental property. The tenant has the right to appeal the court ruling within the 10-day period to vacate.

    If the tenant has not vacated after 10-days, the landlord may request the court issue a Writ of Possession. The Writ of Possession gives the sheriff the legal right to remove the tenant’s property without notice to the tenant on the 11th business day after the order is issued by the court.

    The sheriff does not actually remove the tenant’s possessions, instead supervising the event and ensures the peace. The landlord or the landlord's representatives must remove the tenant's possessions from the rental unit.

Title: Iowa Eviction Laws for Landlords
Content:
# Iowa Eviction Laws for Landlords
In Iowa evictions, the courts deal with the tenant removal from the property aspect and the rent money owed aspect differently. A landlord needs to be thoughtful when requesting an eviction and money damages all at once as it may allow the tenant a longer time period to correct the issue and delay the eviction action.

It's important for an Iowa landlord to be aware of the necessary steps in the Iowa eviction process. A landlord in Iowa that tries to force a tenant out of a rental property on their own not utilizing the legal process may end up being ordered to pay material money damages to a tenant.

**Legally Valid Reasons to Evict a Tenant in Iowa**

In Iowa, a landlord may evict a tenant for the following reasons:

  • The tenant failing to pay the rent.
  • The tenant does not comply with a material term within the lease or rental agreement.
  • The tenant commits an ongoing nuisance or presents a clear and present danger to other tenants or the landlord.

    **There is No Self-Eviction in Iowa**

    A landlord may NOT evict a tenant in the State of Iowa without an order from a court authorizing an eviction. Self-eviction includes any action taken by the landlord outside of the normal legal process designed to force the tenant to vacate the premises. **Iowa Eviction Notice Requirements**

    Payment of Rent Issue

    The eviction notice required in Iowa for nonpayment of rent is 3 days. The written notice needs to advise the tenant of the total amount of rent due including any other fees such as late fees. The notice must also state that the lease will be terminated unless payment is made within 3 days after the notice is served to the tenant. The notice may be served the day after rent is due and the day the notice is served is not included in the compliance period.

    Under Iowa law, a landlord may accept a partial rent payment. The landlord must provide in writing to the tenant a time period in which to pay the remainder of rent due. If the tenant fails to pay the partial rent due amount by the end of the stated time period, the landlord may proceed with the next step in the Iowa eviction process. No additional eviction notice is required to proceed to the eviction.

    If a tenant was given a 3-Day Notice to Quit for nonpayment of rent in the past, the landlord is not required to allow the tenant to pay the entire amount due within the 3 days. The tenant may move forward with the eviction process immediately.

    Clear and Present Danger to Landlord to Tenant

    A "clear and present danger" include provable threats of violence against the landlord or other tenants, an illegal use of a firearm or another weapon, or possession of illegal drugs. A landlord in Iowa must prove the “clear and present danger” through affidavits from witnesses to the event. A police report verifying the event in question may be enough for a court to declare a "clear and present danger."

    A tenant that has caused a "clear and present danger" only receives 3 days notice to quit the rental property. The "clear and present danger" notice informs the tenant that no correction of the issue is possible and he or she must vacate the property.

    Violation of Lease Agreement Term

    Where the reason for the eviction is other than nonpayment of rent or for presenting a clear and present danger, the Iowa eviction notice is a 7 Day Eviction Notice. This notice must state the specific lease provision that has been violated and that the tenant may cure the violation such as by paying for damages caused by the tenant or by removing unauthorized pets or tenants within the 7 day period or the lease will be terminated.

    Month to Month Tenancies

    When a landlord and tenant have a month-to-month lease agreement, the landlord must only give a 30-day notice of eviction. No legally valid reason is needed for the eviction for a month to month tenancy.

    **Service of Notice of Eviction**

    The landlord or representative may serve an Iowa eviction notice by:

  • Delivering the notice to the tenant in person.
  • Delivering it to an adult living in the rental property and obtaining a signature from the adult confirming receipt of the eviction notice.
  • By posting the notice on the unit door, sending the notice by certified mail, and sending the notice by regular mail. If notice is served via door and mail, the notice period starts 4 days after the mail has been postmarked.

    **Court Actions Required in an Iowa Eviction**
  • If the tenant does not pay the total rent due, vacate the rental property, or correct the lease or rental agreement violation, the landlord must being a court action called Forcible Entry and Detainer. This is a legal action for possession of the rental unit only. The landlord needs to initiate a separate legal action to recover any damages or rent owed from the tenant.

  • A landlord that brings a Forcible Entry and Detainer must be careful in what the suit alleges. If the landlord is alleging damages in the Forcible Entry and Detainer, the tenant can request that the action be treated as a money judgment. This can slow the eviction process considerably.

    **Iowa Eviction Forcible Entry and Detainer Actions**

    The landlord will need to present a copy of the served notice and a return of service to the court clerk before filing the Forcible Entry and Detainer. A court will throw out a case where a tenant has not been properly served under the Iowa code of law.

    **Service of Summons and Tenant Counterclaims**

    The tenant is given at least 3 full days between the service of the action and the hearing date. If money damages are requested, the answer from the tenant to the charge is extended to 20 days after service of the Forcible Entry and Detainer with a hearing scheduled several weeks later.

    **Court Date for Tenant Eviction in Iowa Hearing**

    If the tenant does not appear in court, the landlord can gain immediate possession of the property after waiting 3 days and obtaining a Writ of Removal from the court to be served on the tenant.

    If a tenant appears in court and offers to pay the rent in full, the landlord may accept it and dismiss the action. The landlord may also continue to pursue the eviction.

    Stipulated Forcible Entry and Detainer The landlord and the tenant may enter into a stipulated Forcible Entry and Detainer. In this situation, a new hearing date is scheduled to allow the tenant additional time to pay what is owed or to correct the lease violation. If the tenant fails to correct the eviction reason, the landlord is granted immediate possession by the court.

    Hearing for Monetary Damages in Iowa

    If the Forcible Entry and Detainer excluded monetary demands, the landlord can obtain a judgement for monetary damages. The landlord must file a suit in small claims court if the amount is below a certain level or in District Court if the alleged damages exceeds the small claims court maximum amount.

    A landlord can serve the tenant with a separate monetary damages action along with the Forcible Entry and Detainer action. The tenant is given 20 days to file a legal answer to the damages lawsuit or lose the lawsuit.

    **Judgment, Order of Possession, and Writ of Removal in Iowa**

    If the landlord wins the Forcible Entry and Detainer case, the court will issue an Order of Possession and the tenant must vacate the property. If the tenant does not vacate the rental unit within 3 days, the landlord must obtain the Writ of Removal from the court.

    The Writ of Removal is then provided to the local sheriff for delivery to the tenant. The sheriff will return and remove the tenant’s possessions and the tenant if the tenant is not out of the rental property by the stated date.

    Iowa landlords may benefit from seeking legal advice if they are unclear on any aspect of the eviction process in the state.

Title: Oklahoma Eviction Laws for Landlords
Content:
# Oklahoma Eviction Laws for Landlords

If you are a landlord that owns rental property in the state of Oklahoma you'll want to ensure that you understand the eviction laws in the state before proceeding with an eviction. Failure to abide by state laws on eviction can result in a lot of legal problems for a landlord as well as a problem tenant that remains in their rental property.

The Oklahoma eviction process provides an expedited procedure to remove a tenant for 3 major reasons. A landlord may not force a tenant to vacate without first serving the proper Oklahoma eviction notice and by obtaining a court order to do so.

**Legally Valid Reasons to Evict a Tenant in Oklahoma**

A landlord may evict a tenant in Oklahoma for the following legally valid reasons :

  • For the nonpayment of rent.
  • For staying in the rental property after the expiration of the lease term, called a holdover.
  • For a violation of a material term of the lease agreement or rental agreement.

    **There is No Self-Eviction in Oklahoma**

    A landlord may NOT evict a tenant in the State of Oklahoma without an order authorizing an eviction which requires a court hearing. Self-eviction includes any action taken by the landlord outside of the normal legal process designed to force the tenant to vacate the premises. In Oklahoma, a tenant can obtain injunctive relief from a court ordering the landlord to stop any illegal acts to remove them.

    **Oklahoma Eviction Notice Requirements**

    For nonpayment of rent situations, a landlord needs to first serve a 5-day notice to quit the rental property. This notice advises the tenant of the total rent amount due and that it must be paid in full within the 5-day period or the landlord will begin legal action to evict the tenant. The tenant may also avoid the legal eviction by vacating the property.

    Lease term violations besides the tenant's failure to pay the rent require a 10-Day eviction notice that the landlord must provide the tenant. This notice must state the lease term that that was violated and that the lease will terminate in 15-days unless the lease term being violated is corrected within 10-days.

    A landlord may enter the premises after 10-days to repair the property that is the subject of the eviction or lease violation. And then the landlord may submit the repair costs to the tenant as rent on the next rental due date or for the reasonable value of the repairs along with the rent. The eviction may not go forward if this action is taken.

    If the tenant has materially damaged the rental property or has or is causing immediate and irremediable harm to the property or others and fails to quickly correct the violation after receiving reasonable notice to do so, the landlord may immediately begin a forcible entry and detainer action against the problem tenant.

    For month-to-month tenancies, the law in Oklahoma requires 30-days notice before filing for an unlawful detainer. This allows the tenant 30 days to vacate the rental property.

    Service of the notice to quit the rental property may be personally served on the tenant or on a person who is over the age of 12 that has been informed of the nature and intent of the eviction notice. As an alternative option, the notice may be posted in a highly visible place such as a front door but it must also sent by registered mail.

    **Court Actions Required in an Oklahoma Eviction**

    If a landlord has provided written notice to a tenant to vacate the property and the tenant has done so and has also not corrected the reason for eviction, the tenant must file a lawsuit with the local court.

    A landlord needs to file a Summons and Complaint in Forcible Entry and Detainer with the local court to move the eviction action forward.

    **Oklahoma Eviction Unlawful Detainer Actions**

    In Oklahoma, a landlord may demand damages as a part of the unlawful detainer. Past due rent, costs of repair to a rental property due to tenant acts, court costs, and attorney’s fees are all claims a landlord can make against a tenant in Oklahoma. Please note that in Oklahoma, the landlord may only collect monetary damages through an unlawful detainer action if the tenant is served a summons in person.

    **Service of Summons and Tenant Counterclaims**

    An unlawful detainer summons is served to a tenant by a process server or local sheriff 3 days or more in advance of the court hearing on the eviction case.

    If the tenant has any viable defenses or counterclaims against the landlord in the eviction action, he or she is required file and serve a written legal answer to the landlord's claims before the court date. A landlord or a tenant may request a jury trial. A jury trial is typically less favorable for a landlord so avoiding this may be in a landlord's best interest.

    **Court Date for Tenant Eviction in Oklahoma**

    If the landlord and the tenant appear in court the judge will work towards the two parties finding an acceptable settlement if one is possible. The hearing will begin with the landlord 's burden of proving the breach was extensive enough to justify the the eviction.

    **Judgment and Writ of Execution in Oklahoma**

    If the landlord prevails in court and is granted possession of their rental property, the court will issue a Writ of Execution for the landlord. The tenant then has 2-days to leave the property or the landlord may present the Writ to the sheriff to execute and to remove the tenant and their personal property from the rental property. In Oklahoma, the landlord may also have a lien on the tenant’s property. This lien allows them the ability to sell the items if 10-days notice is provided to the tenant via registered or certified mail.
